facts.text: Four persons appeal against sentences of death for double murder of brothers Rattan Singh and Bawa Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BosE J.-Four persons appeal against sentences of death passed upon them in convictions for a double murder, the victims being two brothers, Rattan Singh and Bawa Singh.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted seven persons including four appellants and sentenced all to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge convicted three others also but sentenced all, including the four appellants, to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court acquitted three of the seven accused but sustained convictions of four appellants and enhanced sentences to death.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court acquitted three of the seven but sustained the convictions of the four appellants and enhanced their sentences in each case to death.

facts.text: All seven accused belong to the same village and same faction.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution story is simple. All seven accused belong to the same village and belong to the same faction or party, as Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  calls it.

facts.text: Appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are brothers; Jarnail Singh (acquitted) is son of Battan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Of the seven, the appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are brothers. Jarnail Singh who was acquitted is a son of Battan Singh. The remaining four, including the appellants Sadhu Singh and Kundan Singh,

facts.text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh assaulted Rattan and Bawa about twenty years before the occurrence, were prosecuted, convicted, served short terms of imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are said to have assaulted the two dead men Rattan and Bawa about twenty years before the occurrence. They were prosecuted and convicted and served short terms of imprisonment.

facts.text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh believed to be dacoits and that Rattan and Bawa furnished information to police; this is the motive.

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are also said to be dacoits and it is said that they believed that the two dead men used to furnish information against them to the police. This is said to be the motive for the murders.

facts.text: On 16th June 1951 at about 2 p.m., Rattan Singh was taking food to a well near his house.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is as follows-On 16th June, 1951, Rattan Singh was taking some food out to a well a short distance from his house for himself and his son. This was about 2 p.m.

facts.text: Mst. Punnan (PW 2) heard cries, rushed out with daughter Mst. Charni (PW 11), saw all seven accused assaulting Rattan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Just as he left the house, his wife Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  heard cries of alarm and on rushing out with her daughter Mst. Charni  P.W. 11  saw all seven accused assaulting her husband.

facts.text: Accused beat Rattan Singh till he fell; then rushed to his haveli, assaulted Bawa Singh on cot, dragged him out, beat more; returned to Rattan, more blows; then ran away.

anchor.surface_text: They beat him up till he fell to the ground. As soon as Rattan Singh fell down, they left him and rushed to his  Rattan Singhs  Haveli where the other brother Bawa Singh was lying on a cot, shouting that they would also make short work of him. All seven belaboured him on the cot, then they dragged him out and beat him up some more. After this they returned to where Rattan Singh was still lying on the ground and gave him some more blows. Then they ran away.

facts.text: Weapons: Dalip Singh and Sadhu Singh - barchhas; Battan Singh and two acquitted - lathis; Kundan Singh - takwa (hatchet); Kehar Singh (acquitted) - khunda.

anchor.surface_text: According to Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  the accused were armed as follows The appellants Dalip Singh and Sadhu Singh with barchhas the appellant Battan Singh and two of the accused who have been acquitted with lathis the appellant Kundan Singh had a takwa -a hatchet with along handle, and the accused Kehar Singh, who has been acquitted, had a khunda-a hefty stick with a curved iron end.

facts.text: Rattan Singh had 19 injuries: 2 on head fatal (blunt), 6 grievous others on non-vital parts; death by shock from multiple injuries and brain haemorrhage.

anchor.surface_text: The medical evidence discloses that Rattan Singh had nineteen injuries on his person. Of these, only two, on the head, would have been fatal in themselves. The rest were on non-vital parts like the foot, ankle, leg, knee, thigh, buttock, forearm and wrist, but of these six were grievous. The doctor says death was caused by shook produced by the multiple injuries aided by haemorrhage in the brain due to injury No. 14.

facts.text: Bawa Singh had 16 injuries: 2 serious (head, spleen rupture - blunt fatal), 11 grievous others non-vital.

anchor.surface_text: The other brother Bawa had sixteen injuries but except for two the rest were on non-vital parts. One of the two was on the head and the other ruptured the spleen. The rest were on the ankle, leg, knee, thigh, elbow, thumb and wrist, but eleven of them were grievous. In his case the doctor put the death down to rupture of the spleen.

facts.text: Dalip Singh arrested on 17th June 1951, other three appellants on 18th June; all wearing blood-stained clothes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Dalip Singh was arrested on the 17th June and the other three on the 18th. Each was wearing blood-stained clothes.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted all seven under section 302/149 IPC based on eyewitnesses Punnan PW2 and Charni PW11.

anchor.surface_text: But he was impressed with the evidence of the two eyewitnesses Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  and Mst. Charni W. 11  and believing them convicted each of the seven accused under section 302 read with section 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: High Court considered blood-stained clothes corroboration for four appellants, acquitted other three.

anchor.surface_text: They found corroboration in the case of the four appellants because of the blood-stained clothes and not in the case of the others. Accordingly, they convicted the four appellants and acquitted the others.

facts.text: High Court found at least not less than five persons took part, but acquitted three saying they may or not have taken part.

anchor.surface_text: their conclusion is that  1  generally the story related by Mst. Punnan and Mst. Charni is true  2  that certainly not less than five persons took part in the beating of the two deceased and  3  that the corroboration required by prudence is afforded by the presence of the blood stained clothes

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds convictions of four appellants under 302/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds acquittals of other three stand.

anchor.surface_text: The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have, in our opinion, been wrongly acquitted cannot affect the conviction in the other cases.

facts.text: FIR made by Mst. Punnan at 8:30 p.m. on 16th June 1951, within 6.5 hours, 12 miles from police station, naming all seven accused.

anchor.surface_text: The first information report was made by Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  herself. It was made at 8-30 p.m. within 6- 1/2 hours of the occurrence at a place 12 miles from the police station. ... it names the seven accused, not less and not more,

facts.text: Weapons recovered 30th June 1951, 14 days after, some blood-stained; one set from Dalip's field pointed by Jarnail, another from Kehar's field by Sadhu.

anchor.surface_text: they were not recovered till the 30th, that is to say, not until fourteen days after the murders, and when found, one set pointed out by Jarnail Singh, who has been acquitted, was found in Dalip Singhs field and another set, pointed out by Sadhu Singh, was found in Kehar Singhs field.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside enhancement to death, restores life imprisonment as per Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the discretion was improperly exercised by the learned Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Bawa Singh died very shortly after assault; Rattan Singh a little longer but not long after.

anchor.surface_text: Bawa Singh died very shortly after the assault. The other brother survived a little longer but he also died not long after.

facts.text: Sessions Case No. 30 of 1951 and Sessions Trial No. 5 of 1951 before Sessions Judge Jullundur.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 19th November, 1952, of the High Court of Judicature of Punjab at Simla in Criminal Appeal No. 102 of 1952 and Criminal Revision Nos. 423 and 499 of 1952 of the Court of the Sessions Judge, Jullundur, in Sessions Case No. 30 of 1951 and Sessions Trial No. 5 of 1951.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Bose J. on 15 May 1953.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. May 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BosE J.-

Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 19th November, 1952, of the High Court of Judicature of Punjab at Simla in Criminal Appeal No. 102 of 1952 and Criminal Revision Nos. 423 and 499 of 1952 of the Court of the Sessions Judge, Jullundur, in Sessions Case No. 30 of 1951 and Sessions Trial No. 5 of 1951.

under section 302 read with section 149, Indian Penal Code. He said that as the fatal injuries could not be attributed to any one of the accused he refrained from passing the sentence of death. All the assessors considered all seven accused guilty.

All the assessors considered all seven accused guilty. The learned High Court Judges did not attach any importance to the recovery of the weapons because for one thing they were not recovered till the 30th, that is to say, not until fourteen days after the murders, and when found, one set pointed out by Jarnail Singh, who has been acquitted, was found in Dalip Singhs field and another set, pointed out by Sadhu Singh, was found in Kehar Singhs field.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty. But the discretion is his and if he gives reasons on which a judicial mind could properly found, an appellate court should not interfere.

concepts.interpretation: Death ordinarily in murder unless trial judge records reasons for lesser; appellate enhancement rare, only if discretion improperly exercised; proper when vicarious liability under s149 and fatal blows not identifiable.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule. If it is grounded on the reason that they are closely related to the deceased we are unable to concur.

concepts.interpretation: No general rule requiring corroboration from close relatives; relationship often guarantee of truth unless specific enmity shown; each case on own facts.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: facts. This is number to say that in a given case a Judge for reasons special to that case and to that witness cannot say that he is number prepared t

concepts.unlisted_description: Principle that related witnesses do not require corroboration unlike accomplices

issues.text: Whether conviction under section 302 read with section 149 IPC is sustainable given the inability to ascribe particular fatal injuries to any specific accused and the High Court's uncertainty as to whether at least five persons shared the common object

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear from the above that it is impossible to ascribe any particular injury to any particular person. Therefore it is impossible to convict any one of the accused of murder simpliciter under section 302, nor do the learned Judges attempt to do that. They convict under section 302 read with section 149. But section 149 requires the presence of five persons who share the common object.

issues.text: Whether section 34 IPC can be applied where the accused have not been charged under it even in the alternative

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in this case to have recourse to section 34 because the appellants have not been charged with that even in the alternative, and the common intention required by section 34 and the common object required by section 149 are far from being the same thing.

issues.text: Whether the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration on the ground that they are women, closely related to the deceased, or because the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule. If it is grounded on the reason that they are closely related to the deceased we are unable to concur.

issues.text: Whether the High Court properly exercised its discretion in enhancing the sentences from transportation for life to death in a case of conviction under section 302 read with section 149 IPC where fatal blows cannot be attributed to specific individuals

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty. But the discretion is his and if he gives reasons on which a judicial mind could properly found, an appellate court should not interfere.

He said that as the fatal injuries could not be attributed to any one of the accused he refrained from passing the sentence of death.

arguments.claim: Eyewitness testimony not fully reliable due to doubtful part of story introduced at police instance and requires corroboration as women with fate of seven men

anchor.surface_text: They were not prepared to believe the two eye-witnesses all the way, partly because they were of opinion that a part of their story was doubtful and seemed to have been introduced at the instance of the police and partly because they considered that when the fate of seven men hangs on the testimony of two women ordinary prudence requires corroboration.

arguments.claim: High Court's application of section 149 flawed due to inconsistency: at least five but three may or may not, lacks certainty

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear from the above that it is impossible to ascribe any particular injury to any particular person. Therefore it is impossible to convict any one of the accused of murder simpliciter under section 302, nor do the learned Judges attempt to do that. They convict under section 302 read with section 149.

arguments.claim: Section 149 requires court to find with certainty at least five persons sharing common object

anchor.surface_text: But section 149 requires the presence of five persons who share the common object. It is true that in one place the learned Judges say that there were certainly not less than five present but in the very next breath they say that the three whom they acquit may or may not have taken part in the affair.

arguments.claim: Section 34 not applicable as not charged even alternatively and common intention differs from common object under 149

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in this case to have recourse to section 34 because the appellants have not been charged with that even in the alternative, and the common intention required by section 34 and the common object required by section 149 are far from being the same thing.

arguments.claim: Eyewitness testimony does not require corroboration merely because witnesses are women, related to deceased, or fate of many accused

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule.

arguments.claim: Close relatives' testimony reliable unless specific enmity shown; relationship often guarantee of truth

anchor.surface_text: If it is grounded on the reason that they are closely related to the deceased we are unable to concur. This is a fallacy common to many criminal cases and one which another Bench of this Court endeavoured to dispel in Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan 1 .

arguments.claim: No specific enmity shown against acquitted accused beyond general statements

anchor.surface_text: neither Kundan Singh nor Indar Singh suggests that there was any such dispute in their examinations under section 342, Criminal Procedure Code. Kehar Singh says vaguely that he has inherited land which will pass to the line of Rattan and Bawa if he dies without heirs but he has made no effort to substantiate this.

arguments.claim: FIR prompt and corroborative: names exactly seven accused

anchor.surface_text: The first information report was made by Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  herself. It was made at 8-30 p.m. within 6- 1/2 hours of the occurrence at a place 12 miles from the police station. ... it names the seven accused, not less and not more,

arguments.claim: Weapons recovery provides corroboration as pointed by named accused in fields of named accused and match FIR description

anchor.surface_text: We do not think the discovery of the weapons can be, lightly excluded. One set was pointed out by Jarnail Singh. In itself that might not mean much but it is unquestionable corroboration as against Jarnail Singh unless the fact of discovery is disbelieved or is considered to be a fraud.

arguments.claim: All seven accused participated per eyewitnesses, sufficient for 302/149

anchor.surface_text: Despite that, we agree with the learned Sessions Judge that Mst. Punnan and Mst. Charni are to be believed regarding the main facts and that they correctly named all seven accused as the assailants. On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained.

arguments.claim: In murder cases, death sentence ordinarily unless trial judge records reasons for lesser; appellate court interferes only if discretion improperly exercised

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty.

arguments.claim: Enhancement from life to death improper here due to vicarious liability under s149, inability to attribute fatal blows, no reasons given by High Court

anchor.surface_text: This is a case in which none has been convicted for his own act but is being held vicariously responsible for the act of another or others. ... We are unable to hold that the discretion was improperly exercised by the learned Sessions Judge.

holdings.text: Conviction under section 302 read with section 149 IPC is sustainable as eyewitnesses Mst. Punnan and Mst. Charni are credible and correctly named all seven accused as assailants sharing common object.

anchor.surface_text: Despite that, we agree with the learned Sessions Judge that Mst. Punnan and Mst. Charni are to be believed regarding the main facts and that they correctly named all seven accused as the assailants. On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court independently reviews evidence, finds eyewitnesses reliable based on demeanour, consistency with FIR, recoveries, bloodstains; rejects High Court's uncertainty on participation; applies s149 to vicarious liability.

holdings.text: Section 149 IPC requires finding with certainty that at least five persons shared the common object; conviction cannot rest on uncertain foundation where participation of some is doubtful.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear from the above that it is impossible to ascribe any particular injury to any particular person. Therefore it is impossible to convict any one of the accused of murder simpliciter under section 302, nor do the learned Judges attempt to do that. They convict under section 302 read with section 149. But section 149 requires the presence of five persons who share the common object.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analyzes High Court's inconsistent findings ('at least five' but three 'may or may not'); s149 demands certainty, not probability; applies to facts finding exact seven.

holdings.text: Section 34 IPC cannot be applied where accused not charged under it even alternatively, as common intention differs from common object under s149.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in this case to have recourse to section 34 because the appellants have not been charged with that even in the alternative, and the common intention required by section 34 and the common object required by section 149 are far from being the same thing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar due to no charge; conceptual distinction between intention and object prevents substitution.

holdings.text: Testimony of eyewitnesses does not require corroboration merely because they are women, closely related to deceased, or because fate of multiple accused depends on it; no such general rule of prudence.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule. If it is grounded on the reason that they are closely related to the deceased we are unable to concur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's basis; follows Rameshwar precedent; relationship often guarantees truth absent enmity; each case on facts.

holdings.text: In murder cases, death sentence ordinarily imposed unless trial judge records reasons for lesser penalty; appellate court should not interfere if reasons supportable; enhancement to death rare and only if discretion improperly exercised.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty. But the discretion is his and if he gives reasons on which a judicial mind could properly found, an appellate court should not interfere.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Establishes sentencing principle emphasizing trial discretion, rarity of enhancement; applies to s149 vicarious liability where fatal acts unascribable.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge's discretion to award life imprisonment proper in s302/149 case due to inability to attribute fatal injuries to individuals and vicarious liability; High Court enhancement improper without reasons.

anchor.surface_text: This is a case in which none has been convicted for his own act but is being held vicariously responsible for the act of another or others. ... We are unable to hold that the discretion was improperly exercised by the learned Sessions Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sessions Judge reasoned inability to ascribe fatal blows justifies lesser sentence; High Court gave no reasons; discretion proper in uncertain participation cases.

holdings.text: Acquittals of three accused stand despite being erroneous, and do not affect convictions of others under s302/149.

anchor.surface_text: The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have, in our opinion, been wrongly acquitted cannot affect the conviction in the other cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent convictions; error in one does not taint others.

precedents.case_name: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: fallacy that testimony of closely related witnesses requires corroboration as a matter of prudence

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have, in our opinion, been wrongly acquitted cannot affect the conviction in the other cases. On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear from the above that it is impossible to ascribe any particular injury to any particular person. Therefore it is impossible to convict any one of the accused of murder simpliciter under section 302, nor do the learned Judges attempt to do that. They convict under section 302 read with section 149. But section 149 requires the presence of five persons who share the common object.

On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have, in our opinion, been wrongly acquitted cannot affect the conviction in the other cases. On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in this case to have recourse to section 34 because the appellants have not been charged with that even in the alternative, and the common intention required by section 34 and the common object required by section 149 are far from being the same thing.

On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have, in our opinion, been wrongly acquitted cannot affect the conviction in the other cases. On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty.

We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule. If it is grounded on the reason that they are closely related to the deceased we are unable to concur.

On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions. anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty. But the discretion is his and if he gives reasons on which a judicial mind could properly found, an appellate court should not interfere.
